pageContext.claim: “They got their money long before schedule. They got all their money.”
pageContext.analysis: This is false. U.S. officials became increasingly frantic about the Ukraine aid freeze because the 2019 fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, after which the appropriation would expire. The hold was finally lifted in mid-September, only after intense pressure from members of Congress on both sides of the aisle, but it takes time for the U.S. government to transfer such funds. That’s one reason lower-level officials were so concerned. It turned out that about $35 million of the aid could not be disbursed by the Sept. 30 deadline. For the money to go through, Congress had to pass a law extending the deadline to the fiscal 2020 year.
